pet.name: Name
pet.deleteConfirm: Are you sure you want to delete {{name}}? This action cannot be undone.
pet.initialWeight: Initial weight will be set to {{weight}}g (typical for {{species}})

record.title: Quick Record
record.addPetFirst: Add a pet first to start recording their health
record.selectPetToRecord: Select a pet to log their weight and health
record.selectSymptoms: Select symptoms or add custom notes
record.recordsPerDay: Records are saved per day. Multiple entries today will be merged.
record.weightDropWarning: Weight has dropped by {{percent}}% from last record. This may indicate a health issue.

food.title: Food Guide
food.selectPet: Select a pet to see tailored food recommendations

foodNotes.apple: Remove seeds (contain cyanide). Feed in moderation due to sugar content.
foodNotes.banana: High in sugar, feed sparingly as a treat.
foodNotes.blueberry: Excellent antioxidants. Can stain fur temporarily.
foodNotes.grape: Cut in half to prevent choking. Remove seeds. High in sugar.
foodNotes.orange: MALE RATS ONLY - d-limonene in citrus may cause kidney issues in male rats.
foodNotes.avocado: Contains persin which is toxic to small animals.
foodNotes.broccoli: Can be fed raw or cooked. May cause gas in large amounts.
foodNotes.carrot: Great for teeth health. Can be fed raw or cooked.
foodNotes.spinach: High in oxalates. Feed sparingly to avoid calcium binding.
foodNotes.onion: Toxic to rodents. Can cause anemia and digestive issues.
foodNotes.garlic: Toxic to rodents. Avoid all forms including powder.
foodNotes.cucumber: Good hydration source. Low in calories.
foodNotes.bellPepper: High in Vitamin C. All colors are safe.
foodNotes.tomato: Flesh is safe, but leaves and stems are toxic.
foodNotes.chicken: Cooked only, no seasoning. Great protein source.
foodNotes.egg: Cooked only (scrambled or hard-boiled). High in protein.
foodNotes.mealworm: Excellent protein source for rats. Can be fed live or dried.
foodNotes.cheese: Despite stereotypes, feed sparingly. Some rodents are lactose intolerant.
foodNotes.yogurt: Plain, unsweetened only. Good for probiotics.
foodNotes.peanutButter: Can cause choking due to stickiness. Thin spread only.
foodNotes.sunflowerSeed: High in fat, feed sparingly. Unsalted only.
foodNotes.oats: Plain rolled oats are excellent. Good fiber source.
foodNotes.rice: Cooked brown rice is healthier than white.
foodNotes.bread: Whole grain only. Can expand in stomach, feed small amounts.
foodNotes.pasta: Cooked, plain pasta. Whole wheat is preferable.
foodNotes.timothyHay: Essential for guinea pigs. Good for dental health.
foodNotes.alfalfaHay: High in calcium. Only for young/pregnant guinea pigs.
foodNotes.kale: Rich in vitamins. Best 1-2 times per week.
foodNotes.parsley: High in Vitamin C. Feed in moderation.
foodNotes.cilantro: Most small pets love it. Safe daily veggie.
foodNotes.celery: Cut into small pieces to prevent choking. Low calorie.
foodNotes.strawberry: Remove leaves. High sugar, as a treat.
foodNotes.watermelon: Remove seeds. High water content may cause soft stool.
foodNotes.sweetPotato: Must be cooked. Rich in Vitamin A.
foodNotes.corn: Can feed in small amounts. High in starch.
foodNotes.peas: Can be fed raw or cooked. Good protein source.

settings.title: Settings
settings.reminderDescription: Get reminded to record your pet's health data
settings.healthAlertsDescription: Get notified when weight drops significantly

backup.title: Backup & Restore
backup.backupDescription: Export all your data as a JSON file
backup.restoreDescription: Import data from a backup file
backup.restoreWarning: This will replace all existing data. Are you sure?

notifications.dailyReminderBody: Don't forget to record your pet's health today.

validation.futureBirthday: Birthday cannot be in the future
